However, the legitimacy and accuracy of online information posted by various sources can be exceptionally varied and in some cases untrustworthy, having the potential to harm individuals' health. This paper proposes a method called AutoDiscern to identify high-quality health information using hierarchical encoder attention-based neural networks. Existing methods of evaluating online health information, such as relying wholly on publisher credibility ratings or shallow surface-level assessments, have demonstrated a lack of objectivity and consistency, and thereby frequently fall short of accounting for the specific details and complexities that render health information helpful or devastating. Consequently, innovative objective, cost-effective methods that could furnish elevated sensitivity to quality, an unconditional aspect by which information can be pivotal, are necessary. The proposed hierarchical encoder attention-based neural network includes a long short-term memory recurrent neural network as the encoder and is trained to predict two distinct, fine-grained quality levels, enabling it to make high-quality judgments. The proposed Hierarchical Encoder Attention-based Neural Network performs dimensionality reduction, reduces noise, extracts pivotal content, and detects critically impactful perturbations embodying how informative an article really is. Limits of End-to-End Learning

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: End-to-end learning refers to training a possibly complex learning system by applying gradient-based learning to the system as a whole. End-to-end learning system is specifically designed so that all modules are differentiable. In effect, not only a central learning machine, but also all "peripheral" modules like representation learning and memory formation are covered by a holistic learning process. The power of end-to-end learning has been demonstrated on many tasks, like playing a whole array of Atari video games with a single architecture. While pushing for solutions to more challenging tasks, network architectures keep growing more and more complex. In this paper we ask the question whether and to what extent end-to-end learning is a future-proof technique in the sense of scaling to complex and diverse data processing architectures. We point out potential inefficiencies, and we argue in particular that end-to-end learning does not make optimal use of the modular design of present neural networks. Our surprisingly simple experiments demonstrate these inefficiencies, up to the complete breakdown of learning.

rejected.content: The increasing complexity and variability of real-world tasks have led to the proliferation of deep learning models that incorporate multiple components to perform specific sub-tasks and then combine their outputs to obtain a final prediction. This modular architecture is often referred to as a multi-task learning or end-to-end learning system, where each component is optimized end-to-end to perform its respective task. However, the success of such systems heavily relies on the assumption that there exists a linear or hierarchical structure in the task decomposition, and each component can be effectively optimized without reward signal converging to an unstable equilibrium. In this paper, we investigate the theoretical limits of end-to-end learning, particularly focusing on its capability to tackle tasks that require coordination and communication between components with incompatible or non-hierarchical decision-making logic. Our work explores the fundamental limits of end-to-end optimization, leveraging methods from statistical learning theory to analyze the gradient-based optimization algorithms used to train the constituent components. We derive upper bounds on the performance of end-to-end optimization as a function of the task difficulty, component complexity, and communication opportunities between components. Our results indicate that end-to-end optimization is fundamentally limited in its ability to perform certain tasks due to the inherent instability in the decisions of the components. A fully automated framework for lung tumour detection, segmentation and analysis

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: Early and correct diagnosis is a very important aspect of cancer treatment. Detection of tumour in Computed Tomography scan is a tedious and tricky task which requires expert knowledge and a lot of human working hours. As small human error is present in any work he does, it is possible that a CT scan could be misdiagnosed causing the patient to become terminal. This paper introduces a novel fully automated framework which helps to detect and segment tumour, if present in a lung CT scan series. It also provides useful analysis of the detected tumour such as its approximate volume, centre location and more. The framework provides a single click solution which analyses all CT images of a single patient series in one go. It helps to reduce the work of manually going through each CT slice and provides quicker and more accurate tumour diagnosis. It makes use of customized image processing and image segmentation methods, to detect and segment the prospective tumour region from the CT scan. It then uses a trained ensemble classifier to correctly classify the segmented region as being tumour or not. Tumour analysis further computed can then be used to determine malignity of the tumour. With an accuracy of 98.14%, the implemented framework can be used in various practical scenarios, capable of eliminating need of any expert pathologist intervention.

rejected.content: This study presents a novel fully automated computational framework for the detection, segmentation, and analysis of lung tumors from computed tomography (CT) scans. The proposed framework leverages a deep learning-based architecture, combining convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with a tensor-to-tensor regression approach. A binary classification CNN is employed to detect lung tumors in the CT scans, while a separate regression-based CNN is utilized for accurate boundary extraction of the tumors. A comprehensive lesion segmentation is ensured by incorporating an efficient 3D volume loss function that optimizes the segmentation process. To address the class imbalance issue presented by the predominantly healthy lung tissue in a CT scan, we utilize a focal loss function. Focal loss dynamically adjusts to the varying class frequencies during the training process. An active contour model-based method has been utilized to refine the segmented regions. This method adjusts for localized irregularities and unseen lesions that the CNNs may miss, providing a more accurate contouring of the tumors. Our framework is not limited to a specific dataset and can be generalized across various CT scanners, lung cancer types, and patient populations without incurring a significant decline in performance. The cross-validation of the proposed framework on publicly available datasets along with real clinical samples demonstrated high sensitivity and specificity in tumor detection, outperform

Write an abstract for a scientific paper that has the following title:

EDVR: Video Restoration with Enhanced Deformable Convolutional Networks

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: Video restoration tasks, including super-resolution, deblurring, etc, are drawing increasing attention in the computer vision community. A challenging benchmark named REDS is released in the NTIRE19 Challenge. This new benchmark challenges existing methods from two aspects: (1) how to align multiple frames given large motions, and (2) how to effectively fuse different frames with diverse motion and blur. In this work, we propose a novel Video Restoration framework with Enhanced Deformable networks, termed EDVR, to address these challenges. First, to handle large motions, we devise a Pyramid, Cascading and Deformable (PCD) alignment module, in which frame alignment is done at the feature level using deformable convolutions in a coarse-to-fine manner. Second, we propose a Temporal and Spatial Attention (TSA) fusion module, in which attention is applied both temporally and spatially, so as to emphasize important features for subsequent restoration. Thanks to these modules, our EDVR wins the champions and outperforms the second place by a large margin in all four tracks in the NTIRE19 video restoration and enhancement challenges. EDVR also demonstrates superior performance to state-of-the-art published methods on video super-resolution and deblurring. The code is available at https://github.com/xinntao/EDVR.

rejected.content: In this paper, we propose a novel video restoration method EDVR (Enhanced Deformable Convolutional Networks), which leverages a state-of-the-art approach to address the challenges of video denoising and super-resolution tasks. Our approach builds upon the strength of VSRNet while incorporating more sophisticated techniques for handling temporal and spatial relationships in video content. Conventionally, traditional approaches to video restoration have relied heavily on static convolutional layers, which fail to provide the degree of flexibility necessary to fully capture the temporal coherence present in video data. This inadequacy has been addressed in recent years with the development of deformable convolutional networks (DCNs), which are more adept at modeling complex spatial relationships. However, the application of DCNs in sequential data has been shown to result in slow inference times and is plagued by a series of auxiliary hyperparameters that must be optimized. Our proposed EDVR, on the other hand, extends the concept of deformable convolution to the domain of sequential data by providing two fundamental improvements. Shifted Chunk Transformer for Spatio-Temporal Representational Learning

chosen.content: Spatio-temporal representational learning has been widely adopted in various fields such as action recognition, video object segmentation, and action anticipation. Previous spatio-temporal representational learning approaches primarily employ ConvNets or sequential models,e.g., LSTM, to learn the intra-frame and inter-frame features. Recently, Transformer models have successfully dominated the study of natural language processing (NLP), image classification, etc. However, the pure-Transformer based spatio-temporal learning can be prohibitively costly on memory and computation to extract fine-grained features from a tiny patch. To tackle the training difficulty and enhance the spatio-temporal learning, we construct a shifted chunk Transformer with pure self-attention blocks. Leveraging the recent efficient Transformer design in NLP, this shifted chunk Transformer can learn hierarchical spatio-temporal features from a local tiny patch to a global video clip. Our shifted self-attention can also effectively model complicated inter-frame variances. Furthermore, we build a clip encoder based on Transformer to model long-term temporal dependencies. We conduct thorough ablation studies to validate each component and hyper-parameters in our shifted chunk Transformer, and it outperforms previous state-of-the-art approaches on Kinetics-400, Kinetics-600, UCF101, and HMDB51. Code and trained models will be released.

To address these limitations, we propose a novel deep neural architecture called the Shifted Chunk Transformer that leverages adaptive chunking and attention mechanisms to learn contextualized representations for spatio-temporal data. The proposed model extends the Transformer architecture by introducing a shifted chunking scheme that dynamically partitions the input data into contiguous and non-overlapping chunks, allowing for both spatial and temporal information to flow freely throughout the model. Furthermore, we propose a self-attention mechanism that captures long-range dependencies between chunks by introducing a novel position encoding scheme that includes inter-chunk relationships. The model is trained using a masked language model objective, and we demonstrate its efficacy in modeling different spatio-temporal patterns through a series of experiments on various datasets, including image sequences, video classification, and action recognition. chosen.content: The last few years have seen an increased interest in deep learning (DL) due to its success in applications such as computer vision, natural language processing (NLP), and self-driving cars. Inspired by this success, this paper applied DL to predict flight demand and delays, which have been a concern for airlines and the other stakeholders in the National Airspace System (NAS). Demand and delay prediction can be formulated as a supervised learning problem, where, given an understanding of past historical demand and delays, a deep learning network can examine sequences of historic data to predict current and future sequences. With that in mind, we applied a well-known DL method, sequence to sequence (seq2seq), to solve the problem. Our results show that the seq2seq method can reduce demand prediction mean squared error (MSE) by 50%, compared to two classical baseline algorithms.

The LSTM network is trained to learn temporal patterns in the data and predict the probability of flight delays, while the CNN is used to analyze spatial relationships between flights and predict flight demand. The outputs from the two networks are combined to produce the final delay prediction. The performance of the proposed framework is compared to state-of-the-art statistical models and traditional machine learning methods. Results show a significant improvement in forecasting accuracy, with the proposed framework providing more accurate predictions of both flight demand and delays compared to existing models. However, state-of-the-art models have millions of parameters represented as floats which make them computationally expensive and constrain their deployment on hardware such as mobile phones and IoT nodes. Most commonly, activations of deep neural networks tend to be sparse thus proving that models are over parametrized with redundant neurons. Model compression techniques, such as pruning and quantization, have recently shown promising results by improving model complexity with little loss in performance. In this work, we extended pruning, a compression technique that discards unnecessary model connections, and weight sharing techniques for the task of object detection. With our approach, we are able to compress a state-of-the-art object detection model by 30.0% without a loss in performance. We also show that our compressed model can be easily initialized with existing pre-trained weights, and thus is able to fully utilize published state-of-the-art model zoos.

Boosting Crowd Counting with Transformers

chosen.content: Significant progress on the crowd counting problem has been achieved by integrating larger context into convolutional neural networks (CNNs). This indicates that global scene context is essential, despite the seemingly bottom-up nature of the problem. This may be explained by the fact that context knowledge can adapt and improve local feature extraction to a given scene. In this paper, we therefore investigate the role of global context for crowd counting. Specifically, a pure transformer is used to extract features with global information from overlapping image patches. Inspired by classification, we add a context token to the input sequence, to facilitate information exchange with tokens corresponding to image patches throughout transformer layers. Due to the fact that transformers do not explicitly model the tried-and-true channel-wise interactions, we propose a token-attention module (TAM) to recalibrate encoded features through channel-wise attention informed by the context token. Beyond that, it is adopted to predict the total person count of the image through regression-token module (RTM). Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on various datasets, including ShanghaiTech, UCF-QNRF, JHU-CROWD++ and NWPU. On the large-scale JHU-CROWD++ dataset, our method improves over the previous best results by 26.9% and 29.9% in terms of MAE and MSE, respectively.

Our proposed method, transformer-based crowd counter (TCC), integrates a spatial-temporal transformer encoder with a deformable alignment mechanism to capture both global and local spatial dependencies within and between frames. By attending to relevant image regions and adapting to varying densities, TCC achieves more accurate and robust crowd counting while effectively addressing the primary challenges of crowd density variability, scale, and occlusion. The proposed framework consists of two-stage processing: local context analysis using dense attentive pooling, followed by global feature fusion and decoding. Our experiments, conducted on four diverse crowd datasets provided noticeable results indicating its superior performance relative to existing crowd counting algorithms. The effectiveness of our method for real-world scenarios is also demonstrated through qualitative and quantitative analysis. The experimental evaluation supports the claims of TCC's improved accuracy and efficiency in handling complex and dynamic crowd scenes, including variable densities, partial occlusions, and background clutter. With advances for improving the spatial and temporal understanding of the crowd, TCC has great potential as a tool for event planning, emergency response, and surveillance applications. Furthermore, the scalable and flexible architecture of the model provides a solid foundation for extension to other related vision tasks such as people counting

chosen.content: What goals should a multi-goal reinforcement learning agent pursue during training in long-horizon tasks? When the desired (test time) goal distribution is too distant to offer a useful learning signal, we argue that the agent should not pursue unobtainable goals. Instead, it should set its own intrinsic goals that maximize the entropy of the historical achieved goal distribution. We propose to optimize this objective by having the agent pursue past achieved goals in sparsely explored areas of the goal space, which focuses exploration on the frontier of the achievable goal set. We show that our strategy achieves an order of magnitude better sample efficiency than the prior state of the art on long-horizon multi-goal tasks including maze navigation and block stacking.

In conventional value-based methods, the performance is typically evaluated solely based on the value of the goal being achieved. However, in many real-world applications such as complex decision-making tasks, the exploration of multiple goals often carries its own value. Therefore, the Value-To-Go (VtG) is proposed, a novel metric that quantifies entropy gain to provide a more comprehensive value that combines the value of the goal and its corresponding entropy gain. This paper contributes to developing an algorithm that efficiently searches for goals in a goal space where goals can differ in their difficulties, exploring rates and rewards. Primarily, they frame the Long Horizon Multi-Goal (LHMG) problem as an optimization problem to determine which goals to explore in each episode. Then the Exponential MaxEnt (EMaxEnt) algorithm emerges, a Variance-Reduced (VR) stochastic optimization method, incorporating an entropy bonus designed to encourage exploration. The algorithm exploits the internal dynamics of LMG problems to derive the Maximum Entropy Gain Exploration strategy which overturns the exploration-exploitation trade

Since we are replacing the voxelization with the clustering, we have found it meaningful to name the modified algorithm, with respect to Super-k, as Supervised k Clusters or in short Super-klust. In this paper, we introduce Super-Klust, a novel piecewise linear classification approach that Learns meaningful piecewise linear boundaries without imposing any prior knowledge of the dataset's structure. chosen.content: We consider joint estimation of multiple graphical models arising from heterogeneous and high-dimensional observations. Unlike most previous approaches which assume that the cluster structure is given in advance, an appealing feature of our method is to learn cluster structure while estimating heterogeneous graphical models. This is achieved via a high dimensional version of Expectation Conditional Maximization (ECM) algorithm (Meng and Rubin, 1993). A joint graphical lasso penalty is imposed on the conditional maximization step to extract both homogeneity and heterogeneity components across all clusters. Our algorithm is computationally efficient due to fast sparse learning routines and can be implemented without unsupervised learning knowledge. The superior performance of our method is demonstrated by extensive experiments and its application to a Glioblastoma cancer dataset reveals some new insights in understanding the Glioblastoma cancer. In theory, a non-asymptotic error bound is established for the output directly from our high dimensional ECM algorithm, and it consists of two quantities: statistical error (statistical accuracy) and optimization error (computational complexity). Such a result gives a theoretical guideline in terminating our ECM iterations.

chosen.content: Learning a generative model is a key component of model-based reinforcement learning. Though learning a good model in the tabular setting is a simple task, learning a useful model in the approximate setting is challenging. In this context, an important question is the loss function used for model learning as varying the loss function can have a remarkable impact on effectiveness of planning. Recently Farahmand et al. (2017) proposed a value-aware model learning (VAML) objective that captures the structure of value function during model learning. Using tools from Asadi et al. (2018), we show that minimizing the VAML objective is in fact equivalent to minimizing the Wasserstein metric. This equivalence improves our understanding of value-aware models, and also creates a theoretical foundation for applications of Wasserstein in model-based reinforcement~learning.

Our investigation reveals a previously unknown equivalence between these objectives when using function approximation. Specifically, we derive a novel upper bound on the difference between the two objectives, demonstrating that minimizing the value-aware loss is asymptotically equivalent to minimizing the Wasserstein loss in high-probability states. Our analysis hinges on the pioneering work of Scherrer and Busoniu in linking value functions with MDP distributions, showing that expected value functions can be expressed as expectations of the value function with respect to state visitation distributions. We leverage this connection to formalize a value-aware loss function, and then show that minimization of this objective shares the same desired properties as the commonly used Wasserstein loss in model-based reinforcement learning. A key result of this paper is the development of a novel upper bound, obtained through the use of embedding-based representation of stochastic processes. The bound demonstrates how the difference between the value-aware and Wasserstein losses diminishes as the chosen embedding becomes more precise, with the two objectives converging in high-probability states. chosen.content: Humans can learn a variety of concepts and skills incrementally over the course of their lives while exhibiting many desirable properties, such as continual learning without forgetting, forward transfer and backward transfer of knowledge, and learning a new concept or task with only a few examples. Several lines of machine learning research, such as lifelong learning, few-shot learning, and transfer learning, attempt to capture these properties. However, most previous approaches can only demonstrate subsets of these properties, often by different complex mechanisms. In this work, we propose a simple yet powerful unified framework that supports almost all of these properties and approaches through one central mechanism. We also draw connections between many peculiarities of human learning (such as memory loss and "rain man") and our framework. While we do not present any state-of-the-art results, we hope that this conceptual framework provides a novel perspective on existing work and proposes many new research directions.

In particular, this study synthesizes findings from attachment theory, self-efficacy theory, and situated learning to formulate a dynamic and adaptive framework that recognizes the reciprocal relationships between learner, context, and learning process. By embracing a life-span perspective, this framework acknowledges the significant role of social, emotional, and cognitive factors in shaping lifelong learning experiences. The proposed framework consists of four interdependent components: motivation, metacognition, scaffolding, and emotional regulation. The motivational component emphasizes the importance of intrinsic and extrinsic factors, such as interest, self-efficacy, and rewards, in sustaining lifelong learning. The metacognitive component highlights the critical role of self-awareness, goal-setting, and reflection in guiding learning processes. The scaffolding component examines the influences of social and contextual support on learning, including the intersections between teachers, peers, family, and technology. Write an abstract for a scientific paper that has the following title:

Adversarial Canonical Correlation Analysis

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) is a statistical technique used to extract common information from multiple data sources or views. It has been used in various representation learning problems, such as dimensionality reduction, word embedding, and clustering. Recent work has given CCA probabilistic footing in a deep learning context and uses a variational lower bound for the data log likelihood to estimate model parameters. Alternatively, adversarial techniques have arisen in recent years as a powerful alternative to variational Bayesian methods in autoencoders. In this work, we explore straightforward adversarial alternatives to recent work in Deep Variational CCA (VCCA and VCCA-Private) we call ACCA and ACCA-Private and show how these approaches offer a stronger and more flexible way to match the approximate posteriors coming from encoders to much larger classes of priors than the VCCA and VCCA-Private models. This allows new priors for what constitutes a good representation, such as disentangling underlying factors of variation, to be more directly pursued. We offer further analysis on the multi-level disentangling properties of VCCA-Private and ACCA-Private through the use of a newly designed dataset we call Tangled MNIST. We also design a validation criteria for these models that is theoretically grounded, task-agnostic, and works well in practice. Lastly, we fill a minor research gap by deriving an additional variational lower bound for VCCA that allows the representation to use view-specific information from both input views.

rejected.content: This paper presents a novel extension to the traditional Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) framework by incorporating adversarial elements to enhance its robustness against data noises and outliers. CCA is a powerful machine learning technique used to discover linear relationships between two sets of variables by maximizing the correlation between their corresponding linear transformations. However, its sensitivity to outliers and noisy data poses significant challenges in real-world applications. To address these issues, this paper introduces Adversarial CCA (ACCA), a variant of CCA that incorporates an adversarial loss function to penalize the linear transformations for their failure to capture meaningful relationships between the variables. The adversarial loss function is trained concurrently with the standard CCA objective, effectively regularizing the weights of the transformations to improve their discriminative capabilities and robustness against noisy and erroneous data. Empirical evaluations on several datasets demonstrate that ACCA achieves superior performance in identifying underlying relationships despite the presence of noise and outliers. Furthermore, a detailed analysis of the model reveals that the introduction of the adversarial loss function leads to more interpretable and robust transformations, outperforming traditional CCA in both accuracy and reliability. To overcome the increased computational complexity introduced by the adversarial training process, this work proposes an efficient algorithmic approximation for training ACCA.

Quaternion Convolutional Neural Networks

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: Neural networks in the real domain have been studied for a long time and achieved promising results in many vision tasks for recent years. However, the extensions of the neural network models in other number fields and their potential applications are not fully-investigated yet. Focusing on color images, which can be naturally represented as quaternion matrices, we propose a quaternion convolutional neural network (QCNN) model to obtain more representative features. In particular, we redesign the basic modules like convolution layer and fully-connected layer in the quaternion domain, which can be used to establish fully-quaternion convolutional neural networks. Moreover, these modules are compatible with almost all deep learning techniques and can be plugged into traditional CNNs easily. We test our QCNN models in both color image classification and denoising tasks. Experimental results show that they outperform the real-valued CNNs with same structures.

rejected.content: This paper presents a novel extension to classic Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) by incorporating Quaternion algebra in their architecture. Quaternions are mathematical objects that enable the representation of 3D rotations in a compact form with minimal parameters, making them an attractive choice for overcoming the limitations of traditional 3D CNNs. Inspired by these properties, we propose Quaternion Convolutional Neural Networks (QCNN) that use quaternion-based convolution and pooling operations to extract features from 3D data. By leveraging quaternion algebra, QCNNs can directly operate on 3D input data by representing rotations as quaternions without the need for separate rotation matrices, thereby reducing computational complexity and memory requirements. Specifically, our proposed networks employ quaternion-based convolutional layers that apply to 3D input volumes in a way that naturally preserves the rotational invariance of the input data. Experimental results on several 3D datasets demonstrate that QCNNs achieve state-of-the-art results in object recognition and detection tasks. Our architecture improves performance in terms of accuracy, computational efficiency, and robustness to rotations and permutations of input data. chosen.content: Multi-view time series classification (MVTSC) aims to improve the performance by fusing the distinctive temporal information from multiple views. Existing methods mainly focus on fusing multi-view information at an early stage, e.g., by learning a common feature subspace among multiple views. However, these early fusion methods may not fully exploit the unique temporal patterns of each view in complicated time series. Moreover, the label correlations of multiple views, which are critical to boost-ing, are usually under-explored for the MVTSC problem. To address the aforementioned issues, we propose a Correlative Channel-Aware Fusion (C2AF) network. First, C2AF extracts comprehensive and robust temporal patterns by a two-stream structured encoder for each view, and captures the intra-view and inter-view label correlations with a graph-based correlation matrix. Second, a channel-aware learnable fusion mechanism is implemented through convolutional neural networks to further explore the global correlative patterns. These two steps are trained end-to-end in the proposed C2AF network. Extensive experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of our approach over the state-of-the-art methods. A detailed ablation study is also provided to show the effectiveness of each model component.

chosen.content: 3D semantic scene labeling is fundamental to agents operating in the real world. In particular, labeling raw 3D point sets from sensors provides fine-grained semantics. Recent works leverage the capabilities of Neural Networks (NNs), but are limited to coarse voxel predictions and do not explicitly enforce global consistency. We present SEGCloud, an end-to-end framework to obtain 3D point-level segmentation that combines the advantages of NNs, trilinear interpolation(TI) and fully connected Conditional Random Fields (FC-CRF). Coarse voxel predictions from a 3D Fully Convolutional NN are transferred back to the raw 3D points via trilinear interpolation. Then the FC-CRF enforces global consistency and provides fine-grained semantics on the points. We implement the latter as a differentiable Recurrent NN to allow joint optimization. We evaluate the framework on two indoor and two outdoor 3D datasets (NYU V2, S3DIS, KITTI, Semantic3D.net), and show performance comparable or superior to the state-of-the-art on all datasets.

Dual affine moment invariants

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: Affine transformation is one of the most common transformations in nature, which is an important issue in the field of computer vision and shape analysis. And affine transformations often occur in both shape and color space simultaneously, which can be termed as Dual-Affine Transformation (DAT). In general, we should derive invariants of different data formats separately, such as 2D color images, 3D color objects, or even higher-dimensional data. To the best of our knowledge, there is no general framework to derive invariants for all of these data formats. In this paper, we propose a general framework to derive moment invariants under DAT for objects in M-dimensional space with N channels, which can be called dual-affine moment invariants (DAMI). Following this framework, we present the generating formula of DAMI under DAT for 3D color objects. Then, we instantiated a complete set of DAMI for 3D color objects with orders and degrees no greater than 4. Finally, we analyze the characteristic of these DAMI and conduct classification experiments to evaluate the stability and discriminability of them. The results prove that DAMI is robust for DAT. Our derivation framework can be applied to data in any dimension with any number of channels.

Affine transformations pose significant challenges in the extraction and matching of image features due to their inherent variability in scale, rotation, translation, and shear. Traditional affine moment invariants up to the third order face limitations when dealing with complex distortions, leading to low discrimination and robustness. We introduce a rigorous theoretical framework to derive dual moment invariants, expanding upon traditional invariants. By computing the dual moments, a set of extended invariants that differentiate well beyond the third order are calculated and validated through rigorous mathematical proofs and real-world experiments. This paper provides the theoretical foundation for developing moments up to any desired order n using the lean MoM method. A series of experiments conducted using various affine-transformed shapes demonstrate notable improvements in retrieving the correct objects under an extensive set of conditions, supporting the validity and generality of the dual invariants presented. Key outcomes of this research improves 2D object recognition, tracking, and speed, making this theory highly relevant to areas such as computer vision and image recognition technology. Reducing Bus Bunching with Asynchronous Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: The bus system is a critical component of sustainable urban transportation. However, due to the significant uncertainties in passenger demand and traffic conditions, bus operation is unstable in nature and bus bunching has become a common phenomenon that undermines the reliability and efficiency of bus services. Despite recent advances in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) on traffic control, little research has focused on bus fleet control due to the tricky asynchronous characteristic -- control actions only happen when a bus arrives at a bus stop and thus agents do not act simultaneously. In this study, we formulate route-level bus fleet control as an asynchronous multi-agent reinforcement learning (ASMR) problem and extend the classical actor-critic architecture to handle the asynchronous issue. Specifically, we design a novel critic network to effectively approximate the marginal contribution for other agents, in which graph attention neural network is used to conduct inductive learning for policy evaluation. The critic structure also helps the ego agent optimize its policy more efficiently. We evaluate the proposed framework on real-world bus services and actual passenger demand derived from smart card data. Our results show that the proposed model outperforms both traditional headway-based control methods and existing MARL methods.

rejected.content: In this paper, we present a novel approach to mitigating the phenomenon of bus bunching, a common issue in public transportation systems characterized by excessive wait times and passenger dissatisfaction. Bus bunching occurs when multiple buses following the same route arrive at a stop close together, causing long delays for passengers on later buses and decreased overall system efficiency. To address this problem, we propose a distributed multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, which utilizes asynchronous learning to enable buses to adapt to complex routing scenarios in real-time. Our approach employs a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework based on the proximal policy optimization method (PPO), where each bus learns its optimal policy individually to minimize the arrival time at the next stop, while considering the interdependencies and uncertainty inherent to the system. By training buses in an asynchronous manner, we ensure that the system can adapt to changing operating conditions such as varying traffic conditions, construction, and unexpected service disruptions. Our experiments on a simulated bus network demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly outperforms traditional routing heuristics and baseline reinforcement learning algorithms, leading to a 30% reduction in average waiting times and a 25% improvement in system efficiency. We also show that our approach can handle varying numbers of buses and riders, uncertain arrival times, and updates of new data by adapting

Deep Graph Mapper: Seeing Graphs through the Neural Lens

chosen.content: Recent advancements in graph representation learning have led to the emergence of condensed encodings that capture the main properties of a graph. However, even though these abstract representations are powerful for downstream tasks, they are not equally suitable for visualisation purposes. In this work, we merge Mapper, an algorithm from the field of Topological Data Analysis (TDA), with the expressive power of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to produce hierarchical, topologically-grounded visualisations of graphs. These visualisations do not only help discern the structure of complex graphs but also provide a means of understanding the models applied to them for solving various tasks. We further demonstrate the suitability of Mapper as a topological framework for graph pooling by mathematically proving an equivalence with Min-Cut and Diff Pool. Building upon this framework, we introduce a novel pooling algorithm based on PageRank, which obtains competitive results with state of the art methods on graph classification benchmarks.

The proposed method leverages a GNN-based encoder to transform graph inputs into learnable node representations, denoted as node embeddings. These node embeddings serve as the foundation for subsequent analysis, as they encapsulate both local neighborhood information and network-wide patterns. A unique node classification task is introduced to amend GNN outputs, leading to more nuanced assignment of node features and enhancing discriminative capabilities. Subsequently, a modified diffusion process is utilized to produce a systematic exploration of graph neighborhoods. Utilizing graph embeddings and radial basis functions, the diffusion layer generates highly resolved node-specific subspaces, effectively transforming challenging multi-scale patterns into interpretable and computable visualized representations. Write an abstract for a scientific paper that has the following title:

TFLMS: Large Model Support in TensorFlow by Graph Rewriting

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: While accelerators such as GPUs have limited memory, deep neural networks are becoming larger and will not fit with the memory limitation of accelerators for training. We propose an approach to tackle this problem by rewriting the computational graph of a neural network, in which swap-out and swap-in operations are inserted to temporarily store intermediate results on CPU memory. In particular, we first revise the concept of a computational graph by defining a concrete semantics for variables in a graph. We then formally show how to derive swap-out and swap-in operations from an existing graph and present rules to optimize the graph. To realize our approach, we developed a module in TensorFlow, named TFLMS. TFLMS is published as a pull request in the TensorFlow repository for contributing to the TensorFlow community. With TFLMS, we were able to train ResNet-50 and 3DUnet with 4.7x and 2x larger batch size, respectively. In particular, we were able to train 3DUNet using images of size of $192^3$ for image segmentation, which, without TFLMS, had been done only by dividing the images to smaller images, which affects the accuracy.

rejected.content: We introduce TFLMS, a novel approach to supporting large scale models in TensorFlow through the application of graph rewriting techniques. Traditional large-scale models face significant challenges in terms of inference time, memory usage and computational resources due to inefficiencies in the model's architecture, making it difficult for modern deep learning architectures like BERT and its variants to achieve real-time inference performance. TFLMS addresses this issue by employing graph rewriting to optimize the computational graph of models, removing redundant computations, and enabling the execution of key subgraphs that are reused throughout the model. Graph rewriting, primarily used in functional and symbolic programming, is traditionally applied to small scale programs and models. Our research demonstrates how this technique can be scaled up for supporting large scale neural networks with millions of parameters. Our method includes, graph decorators, a graph rewriting library, a rule set generator, and algorithm for pruning redundant nodes. Our evaluation shows that TFLMS is able to achieve speedup of up to 2.3 speed increase in inference time for BERT-base on GPU's with 1080Ti. The experimental results suggest that graphs of complex models can be safely rewritten in the absence of their context, offering significant opportunities for boosting efficiency, achieving higher performance, and enhancing real-time inference. Monocular Depth Estimation: A Survey

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: Monocular depth estimation is often described as an ill-posed and inherently ambiguous problem. Estimating depth from 2D images is a crucial step in scene reconstruction, 3Dobject recognition, segmentation, and detection. The problem can be framed as: given a single RGB image as input, predict a dense depth map for each pixel. This problem is worsened by the fact that most scenes have large texture and structural variations, object occlusions, and rich geometric detailing. All these factors contribute to difficulty in accurate depth estimation. In this paper, we review five papers that attempt to solve the depth estimation problem with various techniques including supervised, weakly-supervised, and unsupervised learning techniques. We then compare these papers and understand the improvements made over one another. Finally, we explore potential improvements that can aid to better solve this problem.

rejected.content: This paper presents a comprehensive survey of monocular depth estimation techniques, a critical component in various computer vision applications, including robotics, virtual reality, and autonomous vehicles. Monocular depth estimation involves reconstructing a 3D scene from a 2D image captured by a single camera, which increases the computational efficiency of these applications while reducing the necessity of multiple camera equipment. Over the years, numerous techniques have been proposed to tackle the monocular depth estimation problem. These techniques can be broadly categorized into intrinsic and extrinsic methods. Intrinsic methods focus on estimating depth directly from the intensity values of the input image, while extrinsic methods leverage additional information about the imaging process, such as camera calibration parameters, to estimate depth. Intrinsic methods can be further divided into local and global approaches. Local methods typically operate on small patches or pixels within the image and have been shown to be effective, but may be dominated by textureless regions. On the other hand, global methods operate on the entire image and may be vulnerable to noise and artifacts. Local and global methods can also be combined to improve their performance, but these methods often require careful tuning of hyperparameters. chosen.content: Vehicle search is one basic task for the efficient traffic management in terms of the AI City. Most existing practices focus on the image-based vehicle matching, including vehicle re-identification and vehicle tracking. In this paper, we apply one new modality, i.e., the language description, to search the vehicle of interest and explore the potential of this task in the real-world scenario. The natural language-based vehicle search poses one new challenge of fine-grained understanding of both vision and language modalities. To connect language and vision, we propose to jointly train the state-of-the-art vision models with the transformer-based language model in an end-to-end manner. Except for the network structure design and the training strategy, several optimization objectives are also re-visited in this work. This integration is accomplished through a multi-head attention mechanism, which enables the model to selectively weigh the linguistic and visual features in the process of retrieval. Furthermore, we qualitatively assess the usability of our framework by integrating natural language queries issued by average users, sourced from publicly available datasets of realistic scenarios. Our approach offers an innovative two-edged solution to the task of natural language-based vehicle retrieval by harnessing both linguistic and visual descriptions. Style Generator Inversion for Image Enhancement and Animation

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: One of the main motivations for training high quality image generative models is their potential use as tools for image manipulation. Recently, generative adversarial networks (GANs) have been able to generate images of remarkable quality. Unfortunately, adversarially-trained unconditional generator networks have not been successful as image priors. One of the main requirements for a network to act as a generative image prior, is being able to generate every possible image from the target distribution. Adversarial learning often experiences mode-collapse, which manifests in generators that cannot generate some modes of the target distribution. Another requirement often not satisfied is invertibility i.e. having an efficient way of finding a valid input latent code given a required output image. In this work, we show that differently from earlier GANs, the very recently proposed style-generators are quite easy to invert. We use this important observation to propose style generators as general purpose image priors. We show that style generators outperform other GANs as well as Deep Image Prior as priors for image enhancement tasks. The latent space spanned by style-generators satisfies linear identity-pose relations. The latent space linearity, combined with invertibility, allows us to animate still facial images without supervision. Extensive experiments are performed to support the main contributions of this paper.

Building upon the existing deep neural network-based methods, our proposed method leverages an encoderdecoder architecture composed of multiple U-Nets, where the encoder generates a compact representation of the target image in a reference style space and the decoder reconstructs the image with the inverted style. The style inversion mechanism is achieved through a novel style-aware loss function, which combines the mean squared error and the style loss between the input image and its inverted style representation. This represents a significant advancement over the traditional style transfer methods, as it accounts for both image content and style simulating optimal image reconstruction over existing methods. We conduct extensive experiments on images exhibiting true samples and demonstrate the superiority of our model across a range of test images, resulting in noticeable improvements in synthesized images relative to subtle ground truths obtained with a reference image style, with results suggesting that methodology leads to digital artworks â€“ prints or manuscripts - having revitalized exceptional aesthetic attraction. Write an abstract for a scientific paper that has the following title:

AIP: Adversarial Iterative Pruning Based on Knowledge Transfer for Convolutional Neural Networks

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: With the increase of structure complexity, convolutional neural networks (CNNs) take a fair amount of computation cost. Meanwhile, existing research reveals the salient parameter redundancy in CNNs. The current pruning methods can compress CNNs with little performance drop, but when the pruning ratio increases, the accuracy loss is more serious. Moreover, some iterative pruning methods are difficult to accurately identify and delete unimportant parameters due to the accuracy drop during pruning. We propose a novel adversarial iterative pruning method (AIP) for CNNs based on knowledge transfer. The original network is regarded as the teacher while the compressed network is the student. We apply attention maps and output features to transfer information from the teacher to the student. Then, a shallow fully-connected network is designed as the discriminator to allow the output of two networks to play an adversarial game, thereby it can quickly recover the pruned accuracy among pruning intervals. Finally, an iterative pruning scheme based on the importance of channels is proposed. We conduct extensive experiments on the image classification tasks CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and ILSVRC-2012 to verify our pruning method can achieve efficient compression for CNNs even without accuracy loss. On the ILSVRC-2012, when removing 36.78% parameters and 45.55% floating-point operations (FLOPs) of ResNet-18, the Top-1 accuracy drop are only 0.66%. Our method is superior to some state-of-the-art pruning schemes in terms of compressing rate and accuracy. Moreover, we further demonstrate that AIP has good generalization on the object detection task PASCAL VOC.

rejected.content: This paper proposes a novel pruning strategy for Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) that leverages knowledge transfer to achieve state-of-the-art performance with a significant reduction in model size and computational complexity. The proposed approach, dubbed Adversarial Iterative Pruning (AIP), involves modifying the traditional pruning process by introducing adversarial training to preserve important learned knowledge. In contrast to conventional pruning methods, AIP focuses on the iterative refinement of the pruned model by establishing an adversarial game between the original CNN and the pruned network, promoting a more robust model efficient structure. Our method first involves training a pre-trained CNN, then generating a supporting inference model in order to detect and identify the active neurons during network forward passes. Next, we leverage these active neurons to select the pruning candidates. This guided pruning method preserves potentially redundant neurons within the original network. The adversarial and pruned networks then engage in an iterative competition process that dynamically identifies critical neurons contributing to devoted inference accuracy. Experiments using state-of-the-art CNN models and benchmarks demonstrate that our proposed AIP achieves the optimal tradeoffs between model compression and inference accuracy. We also introduce a Stability metric to monitor the effectiveness and robustness of the iterative pruning process. Finally, this measure informs the practitioner of the resulting model

chosen.content: This paper introduces a cross adversarial source separation (CASS) framework via autoencoder, a new model that aims at separating an input signal consisting of a mixture of multiple components into individual components defined via adversarial learning and autoencoder fitting. CASS unifies popular generative networks like auto-encoders (AEs) and generative adversarial networks (GANs) in a single framework. The basic building block that filters the input signal and reconstructs the $i$-th target component is a pair of deep neural networks $\mathcal{EN}_i$ and $\mathcal{DE}_i$ as an encoder for dimension reduction and a decoder for component reconstruction, respectively. The decoder $\mathcal{DE}_i$ as a generator is enhanced by a discriminator network $\mathcal{D}_i$ that favors signal structures of the $i$-th component in the $i$-th given dataset as guidance through adversarial learning. In contrast with existing practices in AEs which trains each Auto-Encoder independently, or in GANs that share the same generator, we introduce cross adversarial training that emphasizes adversarial relation between any arbitrary network pairs $(\mathcal{DE}_i,\mathcal{D}_j)$, achieving state-of-the-art performance especially when target components share similar data structures.

The proposed CASS method leverages the lately popular concept of adversarial training, combining it with the powerful autoencoder architecture to effectively disentangle mixed audio signals into their distinct underlying sources. Traditional source separation methods often rely on the exploitation of prior knowledge about the mixing process or the characteristics of the constituent sources, limiting their applicability to carefully controlled environments. Conversely, CASS seamlessly generalizes to mixed signals with arbitrary characteristics, demonstrating robustness against various mixing methods and diverse source types. We formulate CASS as a two-player minimax game between two networks: the encoder-generation network and the discriminator-denoiser network. The former generates plausible fake source estimates based on the partially observed mixed signal, while the latter evaluates the authenticity and similarity of the generated sources. As this process unfolds, the encoder and discriminator iteratively improve, allowing our method to determine the mixing coefficients that disentangle the mixed signal. This is achieved by optimizing an adversarial loss that complement CASS to standard techniques for source separation. Empirical evaluation on various benchmark datasets confirms the efficacy of CASS, demonstrating advantages over state-of-the-art methods in capturing mixed sources with different durations, rever

Universal time-series forecasting with mixture predictors

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: This book is devoted to the problem of sequential probability forecasting, that is, predicting the probabilities of the next outcome of a growing sequence of observations given the past. This problem is considered in a very general setting that unifies commonly used probabilistic and non-probabilistic settings, trying to make as few as possible assumptions on the mechanism generating the observations. A common form that arises in various formulations of this problem is that of mixture predictors, which are formed as a combination of a finite or infinite set of other predictors attempting to combine their predictive powers. The main subject of this book are such mixture predictors, and the main results demonstrate the universality of this method in a very general probabilistic setting, but also show some of its limitations. While the problems considered are motivated by practical applications, involving, for example, financial, biological or behavioural data, this motivation is left implicit and all the results exposed are theoretical. The book targets graduate students and researchers interested in the problem of sequential prediction, and, more generally, in theoretical analysis of problems in machine learning and non-parametric statistics, as well as mathematical and philosophical foundations of these fields. The material in this volume is presented in a way that presumes familiarity with basic concepts of probability and statistics, up to and including probability distributions over spaces of infinite sequences. Familiarity with the literature on learning or stochastic processes is not required.

The methodology leverages the flexibility of mixture models, allowing each individual predictor to contribute to the overall forecast according to its performance on a specific subset of time-series features. The approach is designed to mitigate the limitations of traditional single-predictor models, which often suffer from overfitting or underfitting when adapting to diverse time-series patterns. The proposed framework incorporates a unsupervised learning algorithm for identifying the most informative features and grouping similar time-series into clusters. For each cluster, the most appropriate predictor is selected based on a set of evaluation metrics, which are calculated using a robust and rank-based approach. The weights assigned to each predictor are then adjusted to reflect their performance on a test set, allowing for a stable and reliable forecast. The framework is applied to real-world datasets, demonstrating its efficacy in improving forecast accuracy for diverse time-series patterns, including sales data from a retail company, energy consumption data from a city, and stock market data from a financial institution. Experimental results show that the proposed method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art single-predictor models in terms of mean absolute error and mean squared error, highlighting its potential for practical applications. chosen.content: We introduce a new machine learning approach for image segmentation that uses a neural network to model the conditional energy of a segmentation given an image. Our approach, combinatorial energy learning for image segmentation (CELIS) places a particular emphasis on modeling the inherent combinatorial nature of dense image segmentation problems. OpenMatch: Open-set Consistency Regularization for Semi-supervised Learning with Outliers

Don't use any formatting and do not repeat the title and use at most 500 words.

chosen.content: Semi-supervised learning (SSL) is an effective means to leverage unlabeled data to improve a model's performance. Typical SSL methods like FixMatch assume that labeled and unlabeled data share the same label space. However, in practice, unlabeled data can contain categories unseen in the labeled set, i.e., outliers, which can significantly harm the performance of SSL algorithms. To address this problem, we propose a novel Open-set Semi-Supervised Learning (OSSL) approach called OpenMatch. Learning representations of inliers while rejecting outliers is essential for the success of OSSL. To this end, OpenMatch unifies FixMatch with novelty detection based on one-vs-all (OVA) classifiers. The OVA-classifier outputs the confidence score of a sample being an inlier, providing a threshold to detect outliers. Another key contribution is an open-set soft-consistency regularization loss, which enhances the smoothness of the OVA-classifier with respect to input transformations and greatly improves outlier detection. OpenMatch achieves state-of-the-art performance on three datasets, and even outperforms a fully supervised model in detecting outliers unseen in unlabeled data on CIFAR10.

Traditional consistency regularization methods, such as pi-models and temp-ensembling, are tailored towards making predictions on the unlabeled data distribution that closely matches the labeled data, which may not be sufficient in the presence of outliers. In contrast, our proposed OpenMatch method imposes a maximum likelihood estimation over an open set of models, encouraging the consistency of learned representations across an open set of models and confining predictive errors to the unlabeled domain. In doing so, OpenMatch leverages the diversity of learned models to span the distribution of possible models, improving the robustness of the learned representations to outliers and interpolating the behavior of deep models that may not capture the tails of the data distribution. We provide theoretical explanations for the effectiveness of OpenMatch through invariance and robustness guarantees, showing improved robustness to uniform weighted sparsification, removal of corrupt labels and data point advantages. The code and open data experiments demonstrate the benefit of our new approach in real-world settings, where the OpenMatch method outperforms both pi-models and consistency regularization methods by large margin in certain cases with significant improvement found across image classification, NLP

chosen.content: Image segmentation has come a long way since the early days of computer vision, and still remains a challenging task. Modern variations of the classical (purely bottom-up) approach, involve, e.g., some form of user assistance (interactive segmentation) or ask for the simultaneous segmentation of two or more images (co-segmentation). At an abstract level, all these variants can be thought of as "constrained" versions of the original formulation, whereby the segmentation process is guided by some external source of information. In this paper, we propose a new approach to tackle this kind of problems in a unified way. Our work is based on some properties of a family of quadratic optimization problems related to dominant sets, a well-known graph-theoretic notion of a cluster which generalizes the concept of a maximal clique to edge-weighted graphs. In particular, we show that by properly controlling a regularization parameter which determines the structure and the scale of the underlying problem, we are in a position to extract groups of dominant-set clusters that are constrained to contain predefined elements. In particular, we shall focus on interactive segmentation and co-segmentation (in both the unsupervised and the interactive versions). The proposed algorithm can deal naturally with several type of constraints and input modality, including scribbles, sloppy contours, and bounding boxes, and is able to robustly handle noisy annotations on the part of the user. Experiments on standard benchmark datasets show the effectiveness of our approach as compared to state-of-the-art algorithms on a variety of natural images under several input conditions and constraints.

Traditional image segmentation techniques often rely on pixel-wise classification, resulting in the need for post-processing to enforce the incorporation of such pre-existing constraints into the segmentation outcome. By formulating image segmentation as the identification of dominant sets within a graph constructed from the image and the given segmentation mask, our method addresses this common shortcoming. Our proposed framework constitutes a novel extension to graph theory by incorporating a new node assignment formula and optimal stability criteria, allowing for the output of dominant sets to be directly influenced by the provided constraints. An experimental evaluation on a standard test data set shows that our method outperforms related approaches, achieving superior results through effective locality preservation, computational efficiency, and conformance to constraints. Our results demonstrate that incorporating constraints directly during the segmentation process offers substantial benefits in practice, particularly when the given masks are spatially contiguous, yielding seemingly simple and effective results. This advocates for the merits of constraint-conjugate image segmentation in achieving more practical outcomes on semi-supervised scenarios where total knowledge imposition is often advantageous. chosen.content: As online shopping prevails and e-commerce platforms emerge, there is a tremendous number of parcels being transported every day. Thus, it is crucial for the logistics industry on how to assign a candidate logistics route for each shipping parcel properly as it leaves a significant impact on the total logistics cost optimization and business constraints satisfaction such as transit hub capacity and delivery proportion of delivery providers. This online route-assignment problem can be viewed as a constrained online decision-making problem. Notably, the large amount (beyond ${10^5}$) of daily parcels, the variability and non-Markovian characteristics of parcel information impose difficulties on attaining (near-) optimal solution without violating constraints excessively. In this paper, we develop a model-free DRL approach named PPO-RA, in which Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) is improved with dedicated techniques to address the challenges for route assignment (RA). The actor and critic networks use attention mechanism and parameter sharing to accommodate each incoming parcel with varying numbers and identities of candidate routes, without modeling non-Markovian parcel arriving dynamics since we make assumption of i.i.d. parcel arrival. We use recorded delivery parcel data to evaluate the performance of PPO-RA by comparing it with widely-used baselines via simulation. The results show the capability of the proposed approach to achieve considerable cost savings while satisfying most constraints.

chosen.content: The key to success in machine learning (ML) is the use of effective data representations. Traditionally, data representations were hand-crafted. Recently it has been demonstrated that, given sufficient data, deep neural networks can learn effective implicit representations from simple input representations. However, for most scientific problems, the use of deep learning is not appropriate as the amount of available data is limited, and/or the output models must be explainable. Nevertheless, many scientific problems do have significant amounts of data available on related tasks, which makes them amenable to multi-task learning, i.e. learning many related problems simultaneously. Here we propose a novel and general representation learning approach for multi-task learning that works successfully with small amounts of data. The fundamental new idea is to transform an input intrinsic data representation (i.e., handcrafted features), to an extrinsic representation based on what a pre-trained set of models predict about the examples. This transformation has the dual advantages of producing significantly more accurate predictions, and providing explainable models. To demonstrate the utility of this transformative learning approach, we have applied it to three real-world scientific problems: drug-design (quantitative structure activity relationship learning), predicting human gene expression (across different tissue types and drug treatments), and meta-learning for machine learning (predicting which machine learning methods work best for a given problem). In all three problems, transformative machine learning significantly outperforms the best intrinsic representation.

chosen.content: Convolutional neural networks (CNN) have had unprecedented success in medical imaging and, in particular, in medical image segmentation. However, despite the fact that segmentation results are closer than ever to the inter-expert variability, CNNs are not immune to producing anatomically inaccurate segmentations, even when built upon a shape prior. In this paper, we present a framework for producing cardiac image segmentation maps that are guaranteed to respect pre-defined anatomical criteria, while remaining within the inter-expert variability. The idea behind our method is to use a well-trained CNN, have it process cardiac images, identify the anatomically implausible results and warp these results toward the closest anatomically valid cardiac shape. This warping procedure is carried out with a constrained variational autoencoder (cVAE) trained to learn a representation of valid cardiac shapes through a smooth, yet constrained, latent space. With this cVAE, we can project any implausible shape into the cardiac latent space and steer it toward the closest correct shape. We tested our framework on short-axis MRI as well as apical two and four-chamber view ultrasound images, two modalities for which cardiac shapes are drastically different. With our method, CNNs can now produce results that are both within the inter-expert variability and always anatomically plausible without having to rely on a shape prior.

chosen.content: Person re-identification (re-ID) is the task of matching person images across camera views, which plays an important role in surveillance and security applications. Inspired by great progress of deep learning, deep re-ID models began to be popular and gained state-of-the-art performance. However, recent works found that deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial examples, posing potential threats to DNNs based applications. This phenomenon throws a serious question about whether deep re-ID based systems are vulnerable to adversarial attacks. In this paper, we take the first attempt to implement robust physical-world attacks against deep re-ID. We propose a novel attack algorithm, called advPattern, for generating adversarial patterns on clothes, which learns the variations of image pairs across cameras to pull closer the image features from the same camera, while pushing features from different cameras farther. By wearing our crafted "invisible cloak", an adversary can evade person search, or impersonate a target person to fool deep re-ID models in physical world. We evaluate the effectiveness of our transformable patterns on adversaries'clothes with Market1501 and our established PRCS dataset. The experimental results show that the rank-1 accuracy of re-ID models for matching the adversary decreases from 87.9% to 27.1% under Evading Attack. Furthermore, the adversary can impersonate a target person with 47.1% rank-1 accuracy and 67.9% mAP under Impersonation Attack. The results demonstrate that deep re-ID systems are vulnerable to our physical attacks.

chosen.content: Medical image segmentation is inherently an ambiguous task due to factors such as partial volumes and variations in anatomical definitions. While in most cases the segmentation uncertainty is around the border of structures of interest, there can also be considerable inter-rater differences. The class of conditional variational autoencoders (cVAE) offers a principled approach to inferring distributions over plausible segmentations that are conditioned on input images. Segmentation uncertainty estimated from samples of such distributions can be more informative than using pixel level probability scores. In this work, we propose a novel conditional generative model that is based on conditional Normalizing Flow (cFlow). The basic idea is to increase the expressivity of the cVAE by introducing a cFlow transformation step after the encoder. This yields improved approximations of the latent posterior distribution, allowing the model to capture richer segmentation variations. With this we show that the quality and diversity of samples obtained from our conditional generative model is enhanced. chosen.content: As a promising area in artificial intelligence, a new learning paradigm, called Small Sample Learning (SSL), has been attracting prominent research attention in the recent years. In this paper, we aim to present a survey to comprehensively introduce the current techniques proposed on this topic. Specifically, current SSL techniques can be mainly divided into two categories. The first category of SSL approaches can be called "concept learning", which emphasizes learning new concepts from only few related observations. The purpose is mainly to simulate human learning behaviors like recognition, generation, imagination, synthesis and analysis. The second category is called "experience learning", which usually co-exists with the large sample learning manner of conventional machine learning. This category mainly focuses on learning with insufficient samples, and can also be called small data learning in some literatures. More extensive surveys on both categories of SSL techniques are introduced and some neuroscience evidences are provided to clarify the rationality of the entire SSL regime, and the relationship with human learning process. Some discussions on the main challenges and possible future research directions along this line are also presented.

rejected.content: The advent of the big data era has led to an unprecedented amount of information available to researchers, transforming the landscape of data analysis. However, the corresponding increase in sample sizes poses new challenges. This paper presents a critical examination of the tension between the big data deluge and the relative scarcity of smaller data sets that are essential for high-impact results. We argue that small sample learning, the process of identifying meaningful insights within smaller data sets, is just as critical as processing large-scale data. As datasets become ever more comprehensive, researchers may begin to invest more time in analyzing large, readily available data sets. This raises the risk of neglecting the viability and insights provided by smaller data sets. The process of small sample learning involves not only data reduction but also strategic selection of variables, focusing only on those most relevant to the research question. This approach can potentially uncover the underlying mechanisms driving phenomena within specific contexts. We provide evidence that small sample learning can be achieved through the development of specialized research design methodologies that prioritize precision and efficiency over the sheer volume of data. By leveraging the growing computing power and techniques such as Monte Carlo methods, simulations, and advanced machine learning algorithms, we can gain meaningful insights from smaller data sets. chosen.content: We propose augmenting deep neural networks with an attention mechanism for the visual object detection task. As perceiving a scene, humans have the capability of multiple fixation points, each attended to scene content at different locations and scales. However, such a mechanism is missing in the current state-of-the-art visual object detection methods. Inspired by the human vision system, we propose a novel deep network architecture that imitates this attention mechanism. As detecting objects in an image, the network adaptively places a sequence of glimpses of different shapes at different locations in the image. Evidences of the presence of an object and its location are extracted from these glimpses, which are then fused for estimating the object class and bounding box coordinates. Due to lacks of ground truth annotations of the visual attention mechanism, we train our network using a reinforcement learning algorithm with policy gradients. Experiment results on standard object detection benchmarks show that the proposed network consistently outperforms the baseline networks that does not model the attention mechanism.

Here, we present the findings of a functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study investigating the neural correlates of visual object detection in a search task. Participants underwent whole-brain fMRI while performing a visual search task, in which they identified the presence of a target object in a complex display of distractors. The display contained easy and difficult objects, and subjects had to correctly identify the objects' location or direction. Our findings indicate that the prefrontal cortex and parietal cortex are indeed activated during the task, but the anterior cingulate cortex was found to be most strongly modulated by attention. Parrot: Data-Driven Behavioral Priors for Reinforcement Learning

chosen.content: Reinforcement learning provides a general framework for flexible decision making and control, but requires extensive data collection for each new task that an agent needs to learn. In other machine learning fields, such as natural language processing or computer vision, pre-training on large, previously collected datasets to bootstrap learning for new tasks has emerged as a powerful paradigm to reduce data requirements when learning a new task. In this paper, we ask the following question: how can we enable similarly useful pre-training for RL agents? We propose a method for pre-training behavioral priors that can capture complex input-output relationships observed in successful trials from a wide range of previously seen tasks, and we show how this learned prior can be used for rapidly learning new tasks without impeding the RL agent's ability to try out novel behaviors. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in challenging robotic manipulation domains involving image observations and sparse reward functions, where our method outperforms prior works by a substantial margin.
